awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Can Disaggregation and Silicon Optical Interconnect Technology Co-exist?
awd_abstract_narration:
About one hundred billion data packets (equivalent to a few thousand Encyclopedia Brittanicas) are transmitted every second from a typical office building. Bottlenecks or breakdowns in modern communication networks instantly impact air travel, healthcare, financial markets, education and entertainment, and national security - in short, every aspect of modern life. To increase bandwidth for the coming decade without commensurately increasing energy consumption, engineers are now using photons (light) rather than electrons (voltage) to carry data between computers. In the near future, photonics may also be used to communicate between microchips inside computers, or between microprocessors and memory. This project addresses a emerging research challenge in ensuring the scalability, control and effective management of massive optically-connected networks such as warehouse-sized data centers.    

Disaggregation replaces motherboard bus architecures with communication networks such as Infiniband and PCIe, thus enabling scalability and controllability, but requires the network to deal with new types of data flows that span several orders of magnitude in bandwidth and latency requirements. These requirements are not compatible with the type of silicon photonic chips that have been designed so far.  This project will use silicon photonics to more effectively enable disaggregation within data centers; leveraging key strengths of optical communications compared to traditional electronic wires: the ability of light of different colors to pass through each other without interference, thus enabling different logical interconnections in a network across the same physical network topology. To test and develop this concept, silicon photonic microchips will be designed and fabricated in collaboration with industry and/or government organizations that host silicon photonic foundry resources. The performance of these innovative communication chipsets will be studied in a optical networking testbed.

por.por_cntn:
In the context of optical networking, the intellectual merit of this project is to study the implementation and benefits of potential disaggregation in silicon photonics hardware, by leveraging the spectral degree of freedom, which is currently underutilized in shorter-distance (e.g., local area and data center) data communication networks. Dense and efficient wavelength utilization has long been adopted for long-haul optical communications, and has been demonstrated in research systems for shorter distances, and is under consideration now for more widespread industry adoption. This project has proposed and demonstrated ways to leverage unused portions of the spectrum by designing small, head-end components in silicon photonics at the transceiver level. The basic idea is that such microchips could be inserted in-line of an existing communication link, without additional fibers or input/output ports, and implement additional or novel functionality which would be difficult to achieve otherwise. We showed how to remotely transmit and receive control information, inserted at and extracted from a small, controlled wavelength shift from the data channel (all optically). At the hardware level, these signals are inserted, and extracted, by silicon photonic filters inserted in front of a traditional optical transceiver, leaving no trace of their presence by the time the light emerges from, or reaches, the traditional building blocks. We also showed the ability to insert and remove data-encoded optical side-channels at very weak amplitude levels, well below the noise floor. The broader impacts of this work are that we develop ultra-compact physical (PHY) level sub-components which can be considered for integration with the rest of the transceiver - using the same fabrication flow at silicon - for the purposes of enabling high-network-layer controllability of the transceiver components in data-center-networking environments, without incurring the insertion loss and latency penalties of separate discrete components for each additional functionality. Students were trained in inter-disciplinary research including device design, fabrication and testing, and networking operations. Publications were co-authored with industry collaborators. Educational materials were developed which bridge the fundamentals of silicon photonic devices and their applications in practical networking. The implications of our research gain in importance as industry adoption of disaggregation increases in large-volume, shorter-distance, low-cost applications.
